description: a(n) = F(n+1)+L(n), where F(n) and L(n) are Fibonacci and Lucas numbers respectively.
comments: Apart from initial term, same as A001060.Pisano period lengths same as for A001060. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 10 2012The beginning of this sequence is the only sequence of four consecutive primes in a Fibonacci-type sequence. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Mar 21 2015
links: Mark W. Coffey, James L. Hindmarsh, Matthew C. Lettington, John Pryce, On Higher Dimensional Interlacing Fibonacci Sequences, Continued Fractions and Chebyshev Polynomials, arXiv:1502.03085 [math.NT], 2015 (see p. 31).
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (1,1)
formula: a(n) = A000045(n+1) + A000032(n).a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2).For n > 1, a(n) = F(n+3) - F(n-2), where F = A000045. - _Gerald McGarvey_, Jul 10 2004a(n) = 2*fibonacci(n-3) + fibonacci(n), n>=2. - _Zerinvary Lajos_, Oct 05 2007G.f.: (3-x)/(1-x-x^2). - _Philippe DelÃ©ham_, Nov 19 2008a(n) = sum(F(k), k = n-3..n+1). - _Gary Detlefs_, Dec 30 2012a(n) = ((3*sqrt(5)+1)*(((1+sqrt(5))/2)^n)+(3*sqrt(5)-1)*(((1-sqrt(5))/2)^n))/(2*sqrt(5)). - _Bogart B. Strauss_, Jul 19 2013
maple: with(combinat): a:=n->2*fibonacci(n-1)+fibonacci(n+2): seq(a(n), n=0..40); # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Oct 05 2007
prog: (MAGMA) [2*Fibonacci(n-3)+Fibonacci(n): n in [2..41]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Apr 16 2011(MAGMA) [GeneralizedFibonacciNumber(3, 2, n): n in [0..39]]; // _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Mar 16 2016(PARI) a(n)=([0,1; 1,1]^n*[3;2])[1,1] \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 24 2015(PARI) a(n)=2*fibonacci(n-3) + fibonacci(n) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 24 2015
author: _Mohammad K. Azarian_
